factoid: Anna Pávlovna gave Borís her shriveled hand to kiss.
Anna Pávlovna introduced Borís to several persons he did not know.
Anna Pávlovna gave Borís a whispered description of each person.
Anna Pávlovna described Prince Hippolyte Kurágin as a charming young fellow.
Anna Pávlovna described M. Kronq as a chargé d’affaires from Copenhagen.
Anna Pávlovna described M. Kronq as a profound intellect.
Anna Pávlovna described Mr. Shítov as a man of great merit.
Anna Mikháylovna’s efforts helped Borís place himself advantageously during his service.
Borís’s own tastes contributed to his advantageous placement.
Borís’s reserved nature contributed to his advantageous placement.
Borís was aide‑de‑camp to a very important personage.
Borís had been sent on a very important mission to Prussia.
Borís had just returned from Prussia as a special messenger.
Borís became thoroughly conversant with an unwritten code he was pleased with at Olmütz.
According to the unwritten code, an ensign might rank incomparably higher than a general.
According to the unwritten code, success in the service required only knowledge of how to get on with those who can grant rewards.
According to the unwritten code, success did not require effort, work, courage, or perseverance.
Borís was often surprised at the rapidity of his success.
Borís was often surprised at the inability of others to understand these things.
Borís’s discovery altered his whole manner of life.
Borís’s discovery altered all his relations with old friends.
Borís’s discovery altered all his plans for his future.
Borís was not rich.
Borís would spend his last groat to be better dressed than others.
Borís would rather deprive himself of many pleasures than be seen in a shabby equipage.
Borís would rather deprive himself of many pleasures than appear in the streets of Petersburg in an old uniform.
Borís made friends with only those above him in position.
Borís sought the acquaintance of only those above him in position.
Those above him in position could be of use to Borís.
Borís liked Petersburg.
Borís despised Moscow.
The remembrance of the Rostóvs’ house was unpleasant to Borís.
The remembrance of his childish love for Natásha was unpleasant to Borís.
Borís had not once been to see the Rostóvs since the day of his departure for the army.
Being in Anna Pávlovna’s drawing room was considered an important step up in the service by Borís.
Borís at once understood his role in Anna Pávlovna’s drawing room.
Borís let his hostess make use of whatever interest he had to offer.
Borís carefully scanned each face.
Borís appraised the possibilities of establishing intimacy with each person present.
Borís appraised the advantages that might accrue from each person present.
Borís took the seat indicated to him beside Hélène.
Borís listened to the general conversation.
Vienna considers the bases of the proposed treaty unattainable.
Vienna doubts the means we have of gaining the bases of the proposed treaty.
The phrase used by the Vienna cabinet was “Vienna considers the bases of the proposed treaty so unattainable … and she doubts the means we have of gaining them.”
The Danish chargé d’affaires said that phrase.
M. Kronq said “The doubt is flattering” with a subtle smile.
M. Kronq was a man of profound intellect.
Mortemart said we must distinguish between the Vienna cabinet and the Emperor of Austria.
Mortemart said the Emperor of Austria can never have thought of such a thing.
Mortemart said only the cabinet says it.
Anna Pávlovna said “Europe will never be our sincere ally.”
Anna Pávlovna called Europe “L’Urope” as a refined French pronunciation.
Anna Pávlovna led up to the courage and firmness of the King of Prussia.
Anna Pávlovna aimed to draw Borís into the conversation by referencing the King of Prussia.
Borís listened attentively to each speaker.
Borís awaited his turn.
Borís looked round repeatedly at his neighbor, Hélène.
Hélène’s eyes met Borís’s eyes several times.
Borís was a handsome young aide‑de‑camp.
Borís had a smile.
Anna Pávlovna asked Borís to tell them about his journey to Glogau.
Anna Pávlovna asked Borís about the state of the Prussian army.
Borís told them in pure, correct French many interesting details about the armies and the court.
Borís carefully abstained from expressing an opinion about the facts he was recounting.
Borís engrossed the general attention for some time.
Anna Pávlovna felt the novelty she served up was received with pleasure by all her visitors.
Hélène showed the greatest attention to Borís’s narrative.
Hélène asked Borís several questions about his journey.
Hélène seemed greatly interested in the state of the Prussian army.
After Borís finished, Hélène turned to him with her usual smile.
